It didn't seem to have any garlic in it at all and just tasted... dirty.  But everything else was awesome. Our food was soooooo good that we had to try dessert.  He got a smore dessert, which was a dense chocolate cake topped with a flambeed marshmallow fluff.  I haven't been able to have marshmallow in years, so that was a real treat!  I got raspberry cheesecake, which did not disappoint!  I am really happy with almost everything about this trip and will definately be back for the "fish." again!

I want to thank The Green Owl for introducing me to the concept of vegan nachos. Vegan "cheese" is usually pretty gross but somehow when its made into a warm, melty sauce and paired with black beans and avocado it is COMPLETELY transformed into a creamy, delicious alternative. This is majorly important as cheese is my ultimate vice - I like cheese on my salad, cheese on my pasta, cheese on my cheese - and now I have a way of eating cheese without eating cheese. THANK YOU GREEN OWL, FOR SAVING ME FROM MYSELF.  Also, great cocktails.
Perfect place for vegans! Delicious food, yummy drinks, no straws in the water (I'm no waste so it matters to me!). Cute place too. Loved it!!

Disclaimer: I am not a vegetarian or a vegan and I love owl decor.  I have wanted to go here for quite awhile and after reading reviews on here I was intrigued to see what type of experience I would have. It turns out that most of the reviews are true and it just depends on what you get and who your waiter is.   I got the Crabby Cake Po'Boy with the kale chips. The crabby cake itself was pretty good but the sandwich as a whole was not spectacular. The chipotle sauce was overly hot without the flavor spicy things should have in addition to the heat and the sandwich was mushy. I understand the lack of meat makes things a little less textured but adding a large leaf of romaine lettuce or slices of cucumber would have added a much needed crunch to the sandwich. As for the kale chips, they were very salty, which was elevated by the fact that we never got a water refill and because of that I couldn't make it through my entire side of salty kale chips.  The comments about portion are true, the dishes are pretty small and because of that, I do think the prices are a bit too much but the vegetarian I went with absolutely loved her fake meatball sub made with eggplant. We both agreed that the sandwiches are good (mine would have been a lot better with the added fresh veggies!), the sides are not good (she got the potatoes which were not very good), and the service could have been better. I agree with the other people who said it is odd that they don't use very much veggies and all of the bread is white...they should embrace being a healthy vegetarian/vegan a little bit more and focus more on veggies and less on meat substitute.

OH GOD THE CRAB CAKES  I've seen them on a few vegan menus before but never tried them until I went to Green Owl. My lady and I ordered them as appetizers and I probably could've just had crab cakes for dinner all night. Instead - I opted for the "fish" fry, after all it was Friday, and I still drool a little bit when I see the two words. I regret that decision, unfortunately. The fish there seems store bought - a perfect patty made into the vague shape of a fish. I can do store bought at home, but from a semi-famous vegan restaurant it was rather disappointing. My advice: get the crab cake sandwich - like I will the next time I go back.  Other notes: - Interior is cool. Beautiful photos of happy animals and brightly painted walls. - Staff likes to hang out at the bar like they are drinking at the bar. Kinda weird. - Drinks are slightly pricey but tasty.
On a road trip to Madison, we ate here multiple times in two days. Really spectacular.

Being a vegetarian, a vegan/vegetarian restaurant should come naturally but I've been to a surprising few I was not a fan of for one reason or another - this is not the case with Green Owl.  Service - Always pretty good with pretty minimal slow-downs. Food arrives promptly.  Prices - Prices seem fair in general although some appetizers seem too high(like Crab Cakes are tiny for a big price). Maybe it's not the portion size that matters but its the first thing you see.  Foods - I'd say this is one of the largest variations when it comes to Green Owl.. its very possible to get something you don't like or like a lot if you try something new. I don't say that in a bad way but some of the recipes are pretty varied and not "safe" for everyone. For instance - the Kale Crisp side was not something I'd like(I'm sure some people out there might like it). But for the rare things I don't like, there is a lot I've come to love such as the "meatball" sub, italian "beef", faux fish stuff and others. I think that is what I really enjoy about the Green Owl is they are constantly offering new things daily while maintaining a very interesting menu. There is still a lot I want to try there.  Special Bonus - I'd say the Green Owl has my favorite Bloody Marys although, strangely, lacking in the "toppings" department.. if they had Celery & Pickles they'd probably easily be my favorite overall Bloody Mary but the liquid/mix/vodka is absolutely heavenly. Try it !

My brother is a vegan, and he was delighted to have a full menu to peruse. ("Now I know why my friends take so long to order," he said, while I imagined him mournfully ordering a salad at every joint.)   I'm not part of The Green Owl's target audience, but I thought everything was pretty decent. The portions were filling, the prices were reasonable, and the Madison Philly tasted pretty good. I was satisfied, if not exuberant. If my brother had a yelp account, I'm sure he'd give them 5 stars.

So, the husband and I decided to start our Wednesday feasting with a very nice walk to The Green Owl. This fine vegan/vegetarian establishment is a gem on the end of the more populated, area of Madison, closer to the industrial area. But don't be a dud, check this place out. Our server was very sweet. We started with two Crabby Cakes, crisp, crab-like cakes, complete with dippin' sauce. I opted for a house kombucha and the husband got a cow-themed beer. We split a reuben and Italian beef sandwich with roasted potatoes and kale crisps. Sooo good! We polished our meal off with a slice of spicy chocolate "cheese cake" that was made with coconut milk. We were silent, as we tend to be during orgasmic food moments. My only suggestion: make the meals a bit bigger. Just a tad. I think being from Chicago left us wanting a little more, but overall, the food was awesome.

Dined here at supper time. Wait for nachos was almost an hour & the order came out wrong. Food tasted good, but based on my lactose intolerant partner's stomach ache upon completion, we question if the initial wrong order contained dairy, which would not have been a problem if the order had been correct. I like the concept & menu items but the measly nachos were not worth $10.50. The server also should have warned us about the wait time & checked on us without our prompting knowing we waited so long for the food.

We just moved to the neighborhood from Willy street and we're right behind The Green Owl which we were super excited about.  Visited for brunch on Sunday around 12:30pm and it wasn't too busy.  I ordered the Paloma cocktail and it was great. Love a good fresh summer drink!   For food I had the Izzy's salad with feta cheese and it did not disappoint. Salad was really fresh with crisp veggies and a light vinaigrette dressing. Comes with either feta or lemon tofu and I can't wait to try the tofu next time! Overall everything was delicious, service was good and I'm excited we now live around the corner.

Great homey food and atmosphere.  I had the quinoa stuffed red pepper which was flavorful and filling.  We had a very friendly server and the restaurant atmosphere is very cozy and comfortable.  The only downside was that there was a pretty long wait for the food.  We received our salad and kale chips along with our meal, although it would have made more sense to get those first to make the wait for the food less significant.  I would recommend to vegetarians and non-vegetarians who are looking for a healthy and flavorful meal.

Good Food, not just good Vegan Food.  Lunch for four as my daughter was leaving for a month to go overseas.  We picked the Green Owl as being both convenient and vegetarian, meeting our two most important criteria of the day.  What we got was also delicious.  As a meat eater, I am often disappointed by the food at vegetarian/vegan restaurants.   Basically they seem to assume that they get points for being vegan. Blech.  Not at the Green Owl.  I have to say, I would be happy to bring anyone there, and expect to be served food that pleases all palates.    All four meals were fine, but by consensus the eggplant meatball sandwich was the winner.  Really good, I mean better than most meatballs you get anywhere else good.    I will say service was slow, and it was not particularly packed (3/4 full?).  Prices were not high, but not cheap for lunch either - 10 to 13 is pricier than most places.  It was for those two reasons that I gave the Green Owl four stars rather than five.  The cinnamon roll cheesecake loved by the three ladies - myself I found the cinnamon to much, but I will concede I am not a huge fan of it.    I look forward to returning.  For a more detailed review, plus pictures, try my blog review, at: http://foodmadeoflove.blogspot.com/2013/01/green-owl-restaurant-review-madison-wi.html

VEGAN food!!!! I was in the area and had to google some place to eat. Now I had had friends come to Madison before and they said it wouldnt be too hard to find vegan options. So glad they were right! A simple google search brought up this vegetarian/vegan cafe.   It seems to be located in a pretty good area, lots of other restuarants, bars and little shops around. I felt safe and intrigued by the area. Parking was fairly decent and free on the street in front of the cafe. A big colorful sign makes it easy to find the place.   Inside is cute. It is a bit small and narrow, intimate I will say. I was greeted right away. I sat at the small bar area to explore the menu, as I was ordering to go. The menu overall looks pretty tastey with a good choice of healthy and comfort foods. There are drinks, daily specials and desserts!   Food was timely and a decent price. Staff was pleasant and even helped me with locating other nearby restaurants with vegan food that was worthwhile to check out.   I ended up getting the following for $30: 1. Orange blossum lemonade: so good!! 2. Wings: buffalo sauce was really good, Im a wimp and definitely needed a drink, but yum and the ranch was tastey. They come in a strange little patty form, but good. I ordered them again on my visit the very next day.  3. Philly: pretty decent, the bread was oh so chewy and I really enjoyed the sandwhich overall.  4. Caramel cheesecake: yup, yum!  5. Side of potatoe and gravy: this was okay, nothing special. 6. Side of kale chips: decent, not my favorite thing but I wanted to give them a shot.    Anyways, very happy with my visit. I stopped by on Thursday early afternoon and it was empty. I stopped back for more on Friday afternoon and it was packed. Definitely recommend it and will return next time I am in the area!!

My girlfriend and I stopped here on the way through Madison.  We decided to get lunch here at about 2 in the afternoon because we were hungry and had heard about how good this place is.  We were quickly astonished how good this place is.  First, the decor, albiet kitschy was pretty well done and fit with the theme of the restaurant's name.  I don't normally go to vegetarian/vegan only places, but I would go here all the time if this place existed close to home.  The food was freaking amazing.  I started off with the in-house-made orange blossom lemonade.  WOW!!!  Not overly done with the orange blossoms, but it was a major component.  A++ on that!  Then, I ordered the TLT w/ Avocado while my girlfriend ordered the Jackfruit BBQ sandwich.  Both were freaking amazing, although I liked the tempeh on the TLT better than the jackfruit.  I think that's just a preference.  I actually thought the vegan TLT was better than a BLT with Neuske's bacon.  I am out of my freaking mind!  It was SOOOOO good.  I had the side of roasted potatoes, and while they were quite good, I should have went with the kale chips like my companion did.  Those were delicious as well.  We followed up with a dessert of some sort of fresh, vegan, raspberry tart with "ice cream".  The "fake" ice cream and "fake" whipped cream topping were amazingly good, and I didn't know they weren't "real".  Mind you, I've had some preconceptions about vegan food, and The Green Owl has squashed them all.  Vegan food can be AMAZING if done in the right way by the right chefs.  A+++++ I will be stopping here pretty much anytime I drive through Madison.

Shame on you, Green Owl.  As the only (?) vegetarian restaurant in Madison, you really seem to rely on that to bring people in, rather than your food.  While I enjoyed my entree (the meatloaf sandwich), my side of crispy kale (which I had to pay extra for) arrived as a charred pile of powder.  How dare you let that out of the kitchen, let alone serve it to a paying customer?  And why/how are your desserts so awful?  I generally will seek out/pay more for vegan desserts, as I find them to taste better than conventional desserts...and there are plenty of vegan bakeries out there to support this claim.  My coconut cream pie was a pile of coconut, on top of a tasteless white paste, and appeared to have been shaped into a triangle to resemble a pie slice.  Service was bad, but it appeared to be just our waitress.  I didn't know there were specials (until I overheard the other servers telling their tables), and the worst is that on the back of the dessert menu was the Friday fish fry special, which I totally would have ordered had I known about it (yes I was there on a Friday night).    My suggestions: - Have 1 or 2 "non-weird" options, so carnivores feel comfortable joining their vegetarian dining companions here.  Something along the lines of a "normal" pasta, mexican lasagna, etc where they wouldn't miss the meat.   - Servers need direction.  I didn't appreciate seeing my waitress walk out of the kitchen chewing a mouthful of food while I sat at my table waiting for food. - The dessert menu as it stands needs to be scrapped.  If you need to bring in vegan desserts from another business, do it.  Those desserts were a fail (I tried part of another one of the desserts and was not impressed).  Food took forever to come out, which I'm willing to deal with but you should put something on the menu about that (there are tasteful ways of saying that the food takes time).  The restaurant was not busy at the time.

Great place!  Crabby Cakes for an appetizer. Very tasty and not dense. I expected dense but they were very airy, which was a plus. My food, Veggie Loaf Dinner was truly amazing! I could seriously eat it 2-3x/week. My partner had the Madison Philly and loved it as well. Ambiance was OK, but given it's a cafe, it was perfectly appropriate. Staff was attentive and good at their jobs. Great lunch experience.

Visited this reastaurant during a short visit to Madison. Compared to the vegan food restos in bigger cities, this didn't compare nor could it compete. However, we were thankful to have found this place to eat due to the lack of vegan options in Madison.  Food was good, nothing spectacular but fair, and portions were also good. Service was great and the deserts was AWESOME! Would visit again and recommend.

Lots of Vegan and Vegetarian options!   Ambience: casual but classy - their light fixtures are pretty cool.   Parking: street; it can be a challenge finding a decent spot given the proximity to other great restaurants and bars   Price: A little pricey for the quantity of food you get  Food: Menu is pretty varied, you can have a noodle dish or a sandwich or a wrap or rice or pasta or a salad. Their kale chips are AWESOME! We got nachos to share and jambalaya and cornbread. The nachos were good but not as good as the ones in Tex tubbs tacos. The jambalaya was lacking in heat but had great flavors and the cornbread was delicious. Food overall was pretty good but nothing on the menu that was crave-worthy.   Dessert: Chocolate lava cake was to die for. It's vegan.. super moist and served warm. Great way to end a meal.

My husband had the schnitzel and I had the crabby cake po' boy.  Magnificent!  We also had the caramel cheesecake and I nearly dropped dead.  My only gripe is about the prices.  Just a tad bit too high.   But lordy, I could eat here every day.
After a few more meals and a few more months, I'm downgrading Green Owl to three stars.  It's still a cool place, and a useful veggie alternative, but honestly, the food is just "meh."

I have never had a bad or even average meal here. My favorite is probably the BBQ jackfruit sandwich at lunchtime.  The interior is gorgeous and the bar has some very tasty concoctions that often feature local spirits.

Fantastic food, fresh ingredients, fair prices. This place has a nice ambiance with young, old and hipster clientele, and performers often eat there before a set at the Barrymore or other nearby clubs. Great owner and nice waitstaff.

LOVE the Green Owl!  Great spot for vegetarians (how fun is it to order off the menu knowing you can order anything)!  Really tasty drinks too (try the lemonade or the chai-tini for an adult beverage).  I have also never been disappointed by the desserts. The Devil Wings are my favorite appetizer and something I crave regularly.  However, I AM going to hold a grudge against The Green Owl, or maybe a silent protest at least, for taking two of my favorite items off the menu: the open faced curry "tuna" melt and the BBQ jackfruit sandwich.  I know they want all the items to be "healthy" but come on, vegetarians need to indulge too!  Maybe they could create a guilty section of the menu and bring these things back with the disclaimer: will induce veggie food addiction and dreams about curry melts.  I mean, it would only help their business.  Since those two are gone I usually go for the crabby cake po boy which never disappoints.  I also wish they would rotate some of the items on the menu and work on making some new creations because as a veggie who cooks, I also make a lot of the items on the menu at home.  Even so, I will keep coming back...waiting for that jackfuit sandwich or curry melt to reunite itself with my taste buds.

I eat mostly vegan now and it's quite useful having a restaurant like this around.  I don't eat out nearly as much as I used to.  I had a great lunch here.  I had the po'boy and a chocolate cake.  The mashed potatoes and gravy were a little disappointing (next time I'll get fries) but everything else was just superb.  The waitress was warm and friendly.  Service wasn't fast but it wasn't too slow either.
We drove 7 hours to get there and arrived 10 minutes before they closed and we still had a great meal. We will be back!

I've been coming here for years. I'm vegan and it's always been the most convenient option. However, for the last 10 or so times I've been, it's been shocking how disorganized and rude the employees are. The wait is now always over 30 minutes even when there are obviously multiple tables open. There is no urgency to take your name, answer questions, seat you, or get you your food. At my last visit, after explicit directions to leave it off, our food came out with dairy in it TWICE. The bathrooms and tables are dirty, and it takes HOURS to be seated, served, and get your bill. It literally makes me uncomfortable how rude the employees are. Totally unacceptable.

Seriously amazing! Just go. I can't wait to have their no meat meatloaf again. And go hungry enough for dessert. Or just go for pie. Whatever. Just go. Thanks, Owl for making veggie eating during our visit a no brainer!
We just happened upon this place down the street from The Chrysalis Salon. Cute place with friendly service! I'm not vegan but the meatloaf was to die for!

First off the food took way too long to come to our table, especially when there was easily more serving staff than customers in the restaurant (we waited approximately 40 minutes.)  Second, I ordered the French toast, which was more of french bread they had toasted with a side of maple syrup. It was generally pretty disappointing to pay $9 for toast.   I can understand not every dish is going to be A+ at a given restaurant, but when something is this awful it speaks volumes. If something is that bad don't put it on your menu in the first place. My girlfriends' Po Boy sandwich was passable, but we were both so peeved that my dish was awful she couldn't even enjoy hers.

I'm not a vegetarian - so take this with a grain of salt...  I was not impressed. The vegan cheese was a decent appetizer. The kale chips were different - worth a try. The roasted potatoes were pretty weak and the po boy was kind of boring.  I liked the interior, but the food just didn't hit the mark. However, I'd give it a second try since they have a big menu. Also - I thought it was a bit expensive for being in Atwood and not using meat?!

Really great vegan and vegetarian meals here (they sell no meat on the premises, but do have eggs for brunch).  Make sure you don't miss their orange blossom lemonade, it is amazing! I recommend the bbq jackfruit and vegetarian italian beef (which is a little salty, as a heads up). Their brunch is also very good, but only available on Sunday for a few hours.  Their desserts are all vegan and made from scratch. Their cheesecakes are to die for.

Solid homemade-style vegetarian food. We LOVED the raw tacos made made with romain lettuce and filled with avacodo, salsa and walnut chorizo so much that we ordered them again for desert! :)  We also had the Gramma's veggie-walnut loaf which was delicious and the Madison Philly with thin-sliced seitan which was enjoyable but could use a little extra punch.
Great spot! Came from NY and thankfully it's one of the handful of places out here that serves awesome vegan fair. If I ever come back I'll know where to stop

WOW! SO glad I decided to get some food here before leaving town.  I am a vegetarian but the husband is not so I rarely eat out at a place like this.  Did it ever exceed my expectations!  Lovely little space, amazingly friendly waitstaff, and the food was to die for.  I was actually full!  Most places have "vegetarian" food which is just bun and some lettuce...these were proper meals.  Even a meat eater could enjoy themselves here.  I will absolutely return here again next time I'm in town and the husband's coming with.
It's a sweet spot with so much potential.  I feel as though it falls into the stereotype of vegetarian food being boring.

The Green Owl Cafe might be my new lover.  I moved to Madison determined to be faithful to my favorite vegetarian restaurant in Boston (well, actually, it's in Cambridge - naturally). But I strayed over to the Green Owl today, and I have a feeling I may stray again.  Many of the dishes here are both approximations of items that include meat, but they still work with the texture and taste of the meat substitute. It's not just, "Remove the meat and let's throw in some tofu." While my BBQ jackfruit sandwich did not taste *just like* pulled pork, the tangy sauce worked with, rather than against, the meaty flavor and stringy texture of the fruit. The "crabby cakes" (tofu and mushroom base, with a spicy chipotle sauce) were simply yummy (that is the most precise description I can think of). The TLT (read: BLT with tempeh instead of bacon) with avocado was divine.  We also loved our desserts (vegan vanilla cheesecake and vegan strawberry shortcake). It is still incredible to me that one can make vegan whipped cream.  Cute decor and nice outdoor seating. Our service was some of the best I've had in years. Our waitress was unfailingly cheerful and seemed to constantly be making the rounds to refill our water, not disappearing into the kitchen for 30 minutes at a time.  I'll be back to try the curry melt, the vegan schnitzel, the jambalaya, and the empanadas. Even the vegetarian meatball sub sounds good.  I also see on their Facebook page that they have monthly raw food dinners. The menu from last month's looks pretty outrageous: cucumber-dill soup, watermelon-tomato salad, hummus and crackers, "BBQ" papaya "steak" with veggie kabobs and corn on the cob, berry cobbler with banana ice cream, all for $25 prix fixe! I'm marking my calendar now.

If it were legal, I would marry the green owl and have little green owl babies and spread them all over so that more people could enjoy this fabulous place!  The bf and I were in Madison visiting his folks, and we wanted to try out a local veggie friendly spot. This restaurant not only met our expectations, but exceeded them.  Ordered: -"Fish" sandwich with vegan coleslaw and tartar and roasted potato for the side. -Vegan chili with cornbread -Kale chips  Dessert: -Raw Tropical Cheesecake -Vegan Chocolate Lave Cake.  I'm not blowing smoke up their ass when I say everything was amazingly delicious. My faux fish sandwich was so ridiculously good, and somehow fishy tasting! You would have never guessed that anything on the plate was actually vegan! My bf really enjoyed the chili as well. The kale chips were crisp and flavorful, but just a tad oily for our liking.  The real stars of the show were the INCREDIBLE desserts. The raw cheesecake had some much flavor and the texture was spot on. The vegan chocolate lava cake was heaven sent. Rich and gooey and delicious!  The servers were friendly and the food was served prompt. For those who have never been there, you should probably not be claustrophobic, as many of the tables are very close together. I didn't mind though cause I got to check out all the awesome food that people were eating!  I can't wait to move to Madison and come here on a weekly basis! And their website tells me they have a monthly raw meal dinner?! Sign me up!

45 min for noodles and a quesadilla.  Slow service and overpriced drinks.  Once we finally got our food it tasted fine, just took waaay too long for our simple dishes to come out.  Not in a hurry to go back.

Let's just start by saying I'm not a vegan, but it was really eye opening to try some wonderfully DELICIOUS dishes from Green Owl! It definitely provided me with some inspiration to try to incorporate more vegan options in my cooking!!! went with a group of 6 and you betcha I sampled from each person's plate. I had never even heard of jackfruit before... as the name implies, it's a FRUIT!! BUT has the consistency of shredded beef/chicken and was used as such in my BBQ wrap and the quesadilla. I'm a fan!!! They also had house-made kombucha... I'm not a fan of this drink in general, but several people I was with ordered it and found it enjoyable.   My only complaint was when I asked for more napkins. See, my boyfriend plopped down at the table when we were seated and knocked over the little flower vase with water, so we used all the napkins at our disposal to soak it up. I explained this and asked if we could have more napkins. The waitress brought us THREE napkins for six people. Wtf... are we sharing napkins now? My sister assumed this was a waste-minimizing action, which I can understand to a certain extent, but Jesus...

Great spot for a drink, vegetarian/vegan food, and to sit. They've done great work with the walls and space, and service is very understanding with customers with diet restrictions or allergies. I'll eat almost anything but my out of town visitor with severe food allergies was delighted with the service and quality of the food.  Empanadas are a little on the small side but taste good and are served with a healthy plate of beans and rice.   Their schnitzel is fast becoming a Madison classic. The potatoes are beautifully roasted, the daily vegetable is fresh from the market, and the fake schnitzel (tasted like a combo of gluten and soy, sort of like the Worthington brand meat replacements) was nicely fried in a rich breading and covered with an excellent vegan mushroom sauce. It's a veritable destination dish for local vegetarians.   The jackfruit barbecue was OK. I do eat meat and the texture and flavor was just a little too off for me, though I basically liked it. Kale chips are good but a little salty and dry. I make them at home sometimes so that's a complaint with the preparation in general; the Owl did as good a version as possible with such a dense leafy green, it's just not the most tasty baked vegetable.   Highly recommended.

I have lived in a vegetarian housing co-op for over 10 years. I am not a rabid meat eater, I have plenty of experience cooking and eating vegan and vegetarian food.   This is not a good place to eat. The only thing worth buying is the vegan cheesecake, that bumps up my review from 1 star to 2.   WAAAAY to much emphasis on "meat replacement" dishes. No, I don't want fake crab cakes. "devil wings" are gross. "unchicken" is gross.   Their non "meat replacement" dishes are underwhelming and overpriced.   For Madison vegetarian options you are better off going to a Thai/Loas place, Himal Chuli, one of the many Indian places in town, ect.. and order vegetarian options. Or come by a housing co-op for a free dinner some time.

I just tried this cafe for the first time and fell in love with the food. It was amazing  to be able to look at the menu and be able to order every single thing! The Devil Wings were my favorite. I love how this restaurant caters to vegetarians and vegans. The service was a little slow, but everyone was laid back and nice. My Overall experience was awesome and I can't wait to go back.
Updated my review because of excellent customer service from the owner. Went back to The Green Owl and the service and food were excellent. I will definitely be back!

Ehhh its ok .... I have had better I got the jamalaya and I thought it wasnt seasoned well, also. But I did love the po' boy  it was GREAT .. SO I guess this place is a hit or miss... also I hate that its not open every day.. I think I tried to go on a monday and it was closed
This place is so cute! I had the TLT Avocado sandwich with Kale crisps and then the mocha chocolate cake for dessert. All vegan and all DELICIOUS. I will definitely be back!

I'm pretty lukewarm about The Green Owl, honestly. And given my borderline veganness, it surprises some people when I tell them that. While I have to give it some credit for being the only 100% vegetarian restaurant in the area (That i'm aware of. Someone should holla at me if there's another), I overall have been to places that do vegetarian/vegan much better than The Green Owl in other cities.  When it comes to strengths, i'll tell you now that The Green Owl has very good desserts, including a vegan cheesecake that was delicious. It was good enough to motivate me to create my own, although that was a failure =/. I'll also say that the menu has a good variety going, so you can satisfy a wide span of cravings there including Mexican, Asian, or traditional American food. This makes Green Owl a pretty safe bet place to go to in certain situations.  On the other hand, I feel like Green Owl has a lot of room for improvement. First off, I'm usually disappointed with the size of the portions I receive. It's usually too small, and sometimes after eating an entree I feel like I could easily down another one, which is not how I should feel after a meal is over. Another critique I have is with the decor and furniture they use in the restaurant. It overall feels very kiddy, and somewhat tacky. I particularly am not a fan of the green chairs. The decor overall makes me feel like i'm in a space for children, which I personally do not enjoy much.  Finally, while I would say that most of the food i've had here is pretty good, it doesn't stack up compared to some of the other vegan gems i've had, like Soul Vegetarian, Native Foods, or Chicago Diner, all in Chicago. One example that springs to mind is comparing the nachos at Green Owl to the nachos at Native Foods. Native Foods nachos are just LOADED, and have very tasty substitute meats and cheeses. Green Owl just doesn't do it as great, and I think that they're both the same price too. A good start toward upping the ante for Green Owl would be completely ditching the Daiya cheese in favor of a nut based substitute. Even if it's more expensive, it would be worth it to be more tasty and healthy.  Overall, I would say that I like The Green Owl, but i'm a ways from loving it. I know that they have been tinkering with the menus lately, so hopefully with some more adjustments, they can turn into a place that I love.

My sister and I are vegetarians, the rest of our family and friends are not.  We've taken our parents, extended relatives and meat-loving boyfriends to this place more than a couple of times to open their palates a little bit. All of the food on the menu is approachable and nothing too "out there" for someone who has never eaten tofu before. The homemade drinks are great, as well as their desserts. The waitstaff are friendly and can answer any questions you have about the menu. When I go, I usually go full bore and order an entree, specialty drink and dessert, so it ends up being a little pricier than most meals. Generally $25-30 with tip.  I do wish they had a couple more menu items without all of the soy meat replacements, though. Some meals don't normally have meat in them in the first place and could be a great addition to their menu.
This place is incredible.  So nice to have a great vegetarian restaurant in Madison.

Oooooo I love this place, I drive from White water at least once a month just to eat here.   I'm vegan and miss the options meat eaters have. This place gives me back that freedom I miss without having to harm a friend.  Thank you Green Owl

Came here last night for take out. I got the Vegan Schnitzel=wow! Very flavorful and nice portion. The car was filled by the aroma and I was salivating even before making it home to enjoy. Glad to have a nice Vegan restaurant close by with a nice variety of options. I will be back!

Great place to get a vegetarian or vegan twist on usual favorites. We had the tofu scramble and the vegan huevos rancheros. Both decent dishes. The blueberry jalapeño waffle was a bit too dense and borderline hard. The best appetizer were the crabby cakes made with TVP and mushroom.   The service was a bit lackluster. They took a while to take orders. They were kinda slow to get the food out and when they did they forgot the crabby cakes. The zinger drink tasted bit soapy and disappointing

I have been meaning to write about this place for months...I was traveling the Midwest (live in California) for work and found this cafe using yelp. I was so excited to find a veg restaurant in Madison. It is located in a very cute little area in what looks like an older part of town. I arrived just after opening and the staff was so friendly. I asked my servers advice on what to have and her suggestions were perfect. The TLA sandwich was so tasty and the cup of chili went perfectly with it. The cafe is also very comfy and I loved the decor. If I ever make it back to Madison, I would defiantly eat here again!

This was our go to restaurant every time we are in Madison, but I have to say, this last time we were very disappointed.  Went here this past Saturday.  Got there at 2:15 and were told there was a 15 minute wait.  No problems. As we waited the bartender asked the couple waiting next to us if they wanted something to drink while they waited, apparently we must have not looked thirsty, because we were never asked.  Finally they seated us at 2:50.  Was given a menu and water, but was not asked if we wanted drinks at the table. We were informed they were out of anything that contained a potato, mind you this was around 3 in the afternoon. So we ordered an appetizer then 10 minutes later we ordered our entrées.  30 minutes after being sat at our table, all we had was two glasses of water, with no ice and my husbands glass had a huge crack in it.  Nothing came to the table.  The couple that was offered drinks from the bartender was seated after us, and they had food and drinks.   Finally we gave up.  We had to be somewhere at 4:30 so we decided to get up and leave. Our Saturday from 2:15 till 3:30... complete waste of time with slightly rude and unorganized staff.  We will not be back.

Maybe the best omelette I've ever had. The right proportions of everything-eggs, veggies, potatoes-and the seasoning was spot on. A relaxed but tasteful place with personality-and friendly college student wait staff. Whenever I'll be in Madison, it will be a priority to return.
Favorite as favorite can be. Loved the Kombucha Tea on tap firstly, and the mushroom vegan crab cake rock. Soups are also so delectable at this quaint little joint!

I am not a vegetarian but I've enjoyed the food. Tried middle-eastern platter, crabby cake po'boy and tlt with avocado. We've also ordered 2 sides: roasted rosemary-garlic red potatoes and kale crisps. They did gave us 2 potatoes instead but once we brought this to their attention we were promptly given a free order of kale crisps.
The best place for vegan love in town!  had the meatloaf plate. SO GOOD.  and huge.  If you like coconut, you MUST get the coconut cream pie.   And their boozy drink specials are legit.

This is the first experience I've had at a (mostly) vegan restaurant. The places is small and very hipster. Our wait staff was nice. My father in-law was taking a long time wrapping up at the end, so we were kind of pushed out at the end because people were waiting. I mean, I get it, but still.  I had these noodles with a peanut butter sauce. Of course I don't remember the name. It was ok. The noodles were spaghetti noodles and I expected some sort of Asian noodle. The sauce actually tasted like peanut butter. My brother in-law has the dragon fruit quesadillas. Now those were awesome!   One thing to mention, for those of us who are meat eaters, remember, there is. I meat here. I recommend getting a dish that does not mock meat, so that you aren't disappointed. I say this because we had some "chicken wings" and while they did a good job, I was disappointed because they were not chicken.   For dessert I had the chocolate ginger cheesecake. AMAZING. Smooth and creamy. The finer not overpowering the chocolate! Yummy.  I'll go back for sure.
I want to give 5 stars but the food isn't that consistent. I usually love their daily chili specials. Nice outdoor seating.

I came back to the Green Owl this past weekend because I recently "liked" them on Facebook  and keep seeing updates (with drool-inducing photos) of their daily specials (also, the owner commented on my last lukewarm review and stated that an influx of Groupon customers may have been the cause of the subpar service we experienced).  Needless to say, the service this time around was very much improved. This time I tried the curry lentil soup, which was thinner than I thought it would be, but very flavorful. I got the eggplant meatball sandwich again (I came so close to ordering the vegan schnitzel but I caved at the last minute and went with a tried and true favorite). Oh my goodness, it was so good. I actually will be trying my hand at making my own eggplant meatballs next week because they are all I want to eat now!   I also ordered the roasted potatoes as a side this time instead of the kale crisps (I found the kale crisps to be a tad too salty). I'm glad I made the switch -- the potatoes are delicious. Usually potatoes are pretty ho-hum and are left behind at the end of a meal, but these were perfectly seasoned and cooked, and I love that the skins were left on.  I still have yet to try their desserts. One day I will have to trek over here just for a slice of their cheesecake.

This place made my day!  We ordered the vegan BUffalo Wings which were to die for. Truly fantastic. The waitress recommended the Blackened Tofu Cuban sandwich which, while spicy as hell, was one of the best meals I have ever had. Being a traveling Vegan, this place was an oasis. Can't recommend it highly enough.

Popped in to TGO for lunch. We had our meal in less than 10 minutes, and it was amazing as usual. If you are looking for vegan comfort food in Madison, this is the place to go. Definitely choose the kale chips as your side. They melt in your mouth!

Food was good (I had a TLT with Avocado, side of quinoa salad), excellent even, which is why it pains me to dock this place 3 stars for the service. I literally waited an hour for a SANDWICH. The waitress was pretty gruff and the place was maybe half full.
What a delicious meal for Mother's Day Brunch...can't quite get their timing of service down, however.  Seriously...waiting 17 MINUTES+ for my credit card and check to come back!  Not cool!

Took a detour on i90 to come visit. Delicious. Absolutely delicious. I had a crabby cake po boy and it was the best thing I've eaten in a while... Friendly staff provided me with a few suggestions and directed me to an awesome local café so I could get my coffee fix before getting back on the road.

There is nothing so incredible as a full out veggie restaurant that serves a filling home style healthy and tasty meal and tops it with chocolate decadence like their Lava Cake! And I might add, great service/low attitude.

Very creative and interesting dishes! Like Switzerland, its a neutral zone where omnivores, vegetarians and vegans can relax and just get along.  I've been here several times and am always impressed by how flavorful everything is and the variety of entrees.  Some favorites: Vegan Schnitzel Shepherd's Pie- daily special

I've been here 3 times and maybe i've just been lucky, but every time, it's been GREAT. And I pretty much thought most everything other people I was with ordered and I snacked on was great too. Last week, I had the avocado blt which was fantastic. I also had a cup of sweet potato chili... I guess it wasn't great... but it was decent. I've also had the crabby cakes and the jackfruit sandwich - both recommended.  Service is friendly. Interior is comfortable and casual. And they have a patio now too.  Note to self: go here way more often!

Food here is amazing. The TLT (tempeh, lettuce, tomato and avocado) is ridiculously good. The staff is friendly, and happy to offer up suggestions. They also have great soup options every day, It is all vegan and vegetarian fare, but don't let that scare you away! The flavors will make your mouth happy.

Amazing selection of vegetarian, vegan and/ gluten-free.  I tend toward the vegetarian that isnt gluten-free  but have tried vegan that was gluten-free free all were wonderful good taste and texture not the usual mushy cheese covered vegs or oil dripping grilled veg  which is so refreshing

Disappointing. Not much different than the blue plate diner sans meat, which is to say, not that it is bad, but nothing here is delicate. And why am I paying $13 for a meal with no meat that is basically diner food?  In my book this place needs to up its game, which basically means that it needs to cook better than I can cook at home.  Unfortunately we won't be back to find out.

If you like tasty vegetable/vegetarian dishes, The Green Owl is not the place for you. The owner stubbornly refuses to offer much more than fake meat entrees. I suppose she doesn't need to, as she seems to be successful with her would-be carnivore dishes. Not wanting one of those, I, as a vegetarian --near vegan-- ordered the Mediterranean plate/platter, which was barely recognizable as such. Much better vegetarian food can be found nearby at Bunky's, The Weary Traveler and Monty's Blue Plate. And at The Green Owl, you're going to pay inflated prices. Very dubiously, I gave it a second try, and my dining companion and I disliked it as much as the first time. I would never go back or recommend that anyone eat at TGO.
Honestly, the TLT avocado sandwich BLEW my mind. Green Owl, you have my heart.

My boys and I road tripped from Dubuque on Mother's Day to eat here, so there was a bit of anticipation built up, I didn't realize they closed at 3, but we arrived at 2:30 and stood in the foyer area waiting to be seated for what seemed like 4-5 mins, the girl behind the counter was wiping things down and refused eye contact, the hostess eventually came to say she be right back, no apology for waiting and no friendly gesture. I felt horribly uncomfortable and unwelcome. When we're sat, they explained it would be awhile before the waitress came, it was about 8 mins, she also had a strange unwelcoming attitude and at this point I considered leaving and if I wasn't with my boys I absolutely would have. My youngest is vegan and was so stoked to be there, I had to maintain my composure. There were about 4 other tables that we could see, and one waiting for food yet. We put our order in and had conversation while we waited. I ordered biscuits and gravy for an app which fully confused our waitress for some reason. After our food came she became really nice and easy going, not sure if she was feeling pressure from back of the house or what but the shift in welcomeness was beyond welcome and noticeable. Both my boys ordered the TLT and were beyond happy with it, biscuits and gravy a bit hard and bland, I ordered the huevos rancheros and it was delicious (pictured) overall, we paid and left adequate 20% gratuity and as we left no one said thank you or good bye (3:25) Certainly a memorable Mother's Day experience. The only way I'll come back is if my boys suggest it.

This restaurant has been on my list for a long time. So happy I finally got to try the food. My waitress was super friendly. I couldn't decide what to order, so I asked for some help and she definitely had the right suggestion. She told me that the best seller was the Tlt, but she said her favorite was the Cajun Blackened Tofu. She also provided the disclaimer that this would be pretty spicy which was the perfect selling point for me.  I ended up getting the tofu with a salad as my side. She was correct that this dish had a kick to it, but it was just the right amount of spice. I would definitely order this sandwich again! The spice also paired nicely with the sweetness of the side salad. I was impressed that this was not your standard side salad. It was mixed greens, with shaved carrots, some quinoa, and a sweet dressing. Next time I would order the dressing on the side as some of the greens got a little soggy.   I'll have to get back soon to try more of the options!

I have eaten here multiple times. On a note of service, some of their best servers don't even work here anymore and I can't imagine what it's like now. The last time I went my server forgot our appetizers completely. In a completely empty restaurant.  If you're a regular here, you're a regular. It's because you've came here from when it first opened and still reminisce about how things were.  For being so pro vegan, you'd think they'd buy food local. They don't. That Sysco truck is big and shiny and isn't doing much for it's vegan name.  There are more reasons that people don't eat meat than just morals. It's flavor, too. And this restaurant provides a lot of imitation meat instead of focusing on making food from scratch that doesn't include making food that tastes like roast beef.  The Green Owl, although thoughtful and a great idea, is poorly executed. Small portions and high prices. Anyone notice that the menu hasn't changed at all?  It's time for a new executive chef and new and interesting approaches to cooking cruelty-free and supporting local.

Me likey!   As a vegan I get asked my thoughts on The Green Owl all the time. It's the only vegetarian/vegan restaurant in town, so I'm bound to have a firm stance, right? Well... not really. Until now, I'd only been once and I had a salad, which is, like, the most snooze-worthy thing you can get.  I went back on a gorgeous summer night and grabbed a table outside. With a Bike Benefits deal I had the option of $1 hummus or a $2 beer. I chose beer. I will ALWAYS choose beer. I ordered a Furthermore Knot Stock to drink and Grandma's Veggie Loaf to eat. The vegetable-walnut loaf came with a tangy tomato glaze, mashed potatoes, and broccoli. The loaf was realllllly tasty and I scarfed it down in about 45 seconds. My dinnermate loved her TLT with avocado (that's tempeh instead of bacon, folks!). I had a super solid time and thought everything was tasty. ME LIKELY A LOT.
Amazing vegan restaurant. The coolest vegan place I have ever been. I wish there were more places like Green Owl in twin cities, MN.

Really yummy food-no wonder they've won best vegetarian restaurant in Madison a few times over.  The café was really cute, complete with owl decorations and green chairs.  We had to wait for a few minutes to be seated, as expected.  However, once we ordered, the food took ~45 minutes to come- but that was the only big downside.  I ordered the Brekkie sandwich and substituted the tofu patty for scrambled egg at no extra charge.  The sandwich was a bit small, since it was served on an English muffin.  I was a bit disappointed by the size, but the taste was absolutely amazing.  I have no idea what they put in the vegan aioli, but it was so GOOD and complimented the vegan cheddar cheese and ripe avocado super well.  Also really enjoyed the fake sausage patty, and I'm usually not one for fake meats.  It came with a huge side of red pan-fried potatoes, which were seasoned perfectly.  My only complaint is with the slow service-but if you're looking for amazing vegetarian/vegan cuisine, you absolutely can't skip out on Green Owl.

It was great to visit a place in Madison with a lot of vegan options. The portions were a good size and everything we had was wonderful. The outdoor seating is also dog friendly. This will be a stop I make anytime I'm in Madison.
Recently went back and the service was stellar!  The buffalo wings and the southwest salad were unbelievably good.  Yay!

7/13/11 Update:  I have gone back a few times now.  The desserts have improved quite a bit.  I've tried a couple of the sandwiches, and they've been on the better side of ok.  Unfortunately, I'm scared off of the schnitzel, so I don't know if it's changed or not.  Updating to 3 stars.  I'm still a bit disappointed by the offerings, as it's a fake meat inspired menu, and a bit overpriced for the portions.  ******************************************  Original Post************** The specials are FANTASTIC!  I have been blown away by every single special I've had.  They've had a fairly wide range, so it's fair to say that they put a lot of effort into them.  Sadly, the regular menu items have been mediocre.  I really wish they didn't have a menu that was designed around everything being 'fake meat', rather than appreciating the wide world of food outside of the tiny kingdom of meat for what it is and the flavors it offers. (Very sadly, as I was SUPER looking forward to it, the vegan schnitzle was so dry and hard, I couldn't even cut it).  Interesting drink specials, too. :D   I really REALLY want to like the desserts. However, they've been super hit or miss.  Example: 3 times I've tried the lava cake. It's one of my favorite desserts. 1 out of the 3 times it was palatable. The others it was a briquette. I recognize that could be restaurant staff overheating it before serving; but even then, it shouldn't be that hard and dry.  Of the cheesecake dessert specials, which they seem to have frequently, one was divine (cherry amaretto), the others have been 'meh'.  The S'more pie was fantastic the first time, and then I had it twice afterwards and it was completely different each time- only good the first.
Green Owl Vegetarian restaurant is not to be missed. Request the Green Owl hot sauce , "cheesesteak" sandwich & a New Glarus #octoberfest  (only available in #Wisconsin)? #happyHourSomewhere

First--I am not vegan or a vegetarian; I love meat as much as the next person. Prior to my first  visit, I was quite hesitant as you can imagine but decided to give it a shot. And...this place is AMAZING! A perfect and much needed restaurant for Madison. Everything I've tried so far has been delicious. (I've gone back quite a few times). My favorite dishes are the Groundnut Stew, the raw taco platter, and the crabby cakes. My suggestion: never leave without ordering a slice of pure heaven cheesecake/dessert. It makes me feel better about myself since it's vegan. ;) I usually dine on week nights since they're not as busy. Service is always pleasant and courteous. Needless to say, I will be returning for more vegan goodness.

There are few places I can go that I don't have to worry about gluten free and vegan options being a complicated order.  The food is made with heart and the wholesome goodness leaves you walking out with a positive energy and a full belly.

Very disappointed. I'm vegan, so I was super excited to try this place. My friend and I split the vegan schnitzel and got soup on the side, a tofu curry. The soup was good, but the entree was all kinds of wrong. The schnitzel tasted like they reheated a frozen patty and put some mushroom sauce on top. The potatoes needed lots of extra salt/pepper to taste like anything, and the broccoli was flavorless. ALL WERE COLD. We were going to get dessert, but decided to get some vegan cupcakes at the Coop down the street. EXCELLENT CHOICE. Wouldn't go again.
So they are not kidding, this place has no animal protein at all.   Does have a dog friendly patio and pleasant  service.

I'm not a vegetarian but I almost always order something vegetarian anyway when I go out to eat. Naturally I thought then that going to a vegetarian place would be a good idea. I was disappointed.  Nothing on the menu was very tempting, mainly because it all seems to be classic meat dishes with meat replacements. I would've loved to see a list of interesting soups and salads.   The spinach artichoke dip tasted pretty terrible which I didn't think was possible and the crackers it came with tasted like cardboard. The other dishes went similarly.  I will say they had really interesting, delicious cocktails!

Wandered in recently before a concert at the Barrymore. Place is absolutely adorable and the staff were so nice. I had a few fairly idiotic questions as there was plenty on the menu I wasn't familiar with. My server was happy to explain and even seemed really excited to talk about what they do.  The menu was so much more "meaty" so to speak than some other places that cater to the vegan/vegetarian market....Meaning you'll find some very filling and unique things like Vegan Schnitzel (Which was delicious by the way) and their take on pulled-unpork and uncrab patties.  Very local and fresh ingredients. Decent prices. Nice beer list and signature cocktails infused in house.   I am neither a vegan nor a vegetarian and I was very satisfied with my experience. It's work checking out.

Praise be, Madison finally has a vegetarian restaurant! Best of all, The Green Owl fits the bill as a go-to spot whenever you happen to be in town---it's casual, affordable and has a good-sized menu so you can try something new each time you stop by. About 80% of the menu is vegan and all vegan items are labeled. Green Owl also has rotating vegan dessert specials daily. If you're in Madison and you're vegan or vegetarian or just like good food, this place should be at the top of your list.  The space itself is lovely: bright; colorful; retro-mod with a bistro-bar ambience. The bar up front is a bit cramped and too close to the front door (a chilly spot in winter) but it'll be great in the summer. Green Owl has a good selection of unusual wines and beers.  I do wish that Green Owl was a bit more casual and offered original coffee & tea drinks, so that the space could double-up as a coffee shop as well. I think it would draw people in and (hopefully) steal away customers from less veg-friendly places in that area. It would also save me the hassle of driving a mile down the road to the Williamson Street Co-op to pick up a fresh chai for my frequent trips to/fro Minneapolis to/fro Chicago.  I first time I went I had a BBQ jackfruit sandwich with roasted potatoes ($8). The sandwich tasted good on a whole, but was not without flaws. For one thing, there wasn't enough jackfruit---it seemed like only a few small pieces. Secondly, I don't know if mixing coleslaw on the sandwich worked with the smoky-sweet flavor of the barbecue sauce. Lastly, the artisan bread was not toasted enough, and was too thick; I would have preferred a thinner, toasted whole wheat option. The roasted potatoes were a tasty side, though.  I also had a slice of coconut creme pie ($6) for dessert. This was spectacular. It was oh-so-subtly sweet, with wonderfully airy "creme" and nice crispy-crumbly notes from shaved coconut and a great crust.   The second time I went to Green Owl I had the "vegetarian Italian beef" (which is vegan; $9). This sandwich was excellent and tasted just like Italian beef sandwiches, though with seitan. The bread got nicely soggy and wet and brought back many memories. I think the seitan could have been marinated more in the sauce, but it was a great-tasting meal and much better than the BBQ jackfruit sandwich. I got it with a side of kale crisps, which were also awesome, and not usually seen on menus. The portion size could have been slightly larger given the price, but this was definitely a high-grade meal and well-executed.  For dessert I had a slice of New York cheesecake ($6) which came topped with strawberries, whipped cream, caramel drizzle, and one fresh mint leaf. This cheesecake was wonderful and one of the best I've ever had. It was rich, but not too sweet, and the interplay of the caramel, strawberries, mint and whipped cream was divine.  On my third visit, I had the vegan schnitzel ($13) which comes with either a soup or salad. The soup was an amazing winter vegetable medley that was quite spicy (probably too much so for most people, but just perfect for me). The schnitzel itself was also spectacular---I've never had real schnitzel, but this was a breaded, meaty marvel covered in a savory mushroom stroganoff-style sauce. I enjoyed the garlic green beans and roasted red potatoes that also came with the dish. For dessert I got a chocolate mousse tart ($6) which came with raspberry sauce and soy whipped cream; this was delicious and the chocolate had a slightly minty flavor. Green Owl consistently does excellent desserts.  For the fourth visit I had their crabby cakes sandwich ($9) which was tasty on fluffy white bread. It seemed a bit small for the price tag, but it was still good. On a whole, I would recommend the Italian beef or the schnitzel over anything else (I have yet to try their jambalaya, however). I also had a slice of key lime cheesecake ($6) which was good, and had a nicely browned/baked top layer, though it wasn't as good as the New York cheesecake I'd had a couple months back.  The service is always friendly and helpful. On at least two separate occasions my server also got me samples of the other available vegan dessert of the day, which was a great way to help me decide which dessert to choose.  Every town should have an all-purpose veg. spot like this one. I'm glad Green Owl is around, though I'm afraid it'll prevent me from ever trying other places in Madison!

My fiancé and I went here last night for a full course meal. We ordered the crabby cakes which took awhile (heard the kitchen was training new hires) and when they came out we were a bit disappointed. There was too much sauce on each cake that I scrapped half off. However, our entrees were great! We had the veggie loaf and the philly and finished off with the coconut key lime cheesecake. We'll be back for sure since the food and service was great!

My absolutely favorite place in town! For me, part of the fun of dining out is deciding what to order, and the more options from which to choose, the better. As a vegan, I cannot overstate how wonderful it is to go into a place where the majority of items are vegan. When I go into pretty much any other restaurant in town, I scan the menu and the choices are narrowed down to one or two--that's like having my choice made for me! Plus, that also means that even if the dish is good, I won't frequent the place because who wants to eat the one same thing over & over?  That being said, the food at Green Owl is spectacular. Creatively & thoughtfully prepared, and whether you're looking for uber-healthful raw food or somewhat decadent "comfort food", you'll find it at the Green Owl. Some reviews on here have complained about the prices, but bear in mind that the Green Owl chef attempts to keep ingredients locally sourced, and the presentation is artful. This isn't some Sysco stuff slopped onto a plate!  In other words, worth every penny!  If you're vegetarian or vegan, this is the place for you. And I've brought several omnivore friends who loved it as well--and came back to the Green Owl on their own!

Adorable! Great nice people, cutest anthropologie-esque decor, and great comfort food. The vegan schnitzel, bbq jackfruit sandwich, crabby cakes are all great, but the crispy kale chips were definitely the most addictive. I can't wait to come back!

Mixed bag here.  To start the appropriate green meal, I biked here on a warm Thursday. And of course that made me very thirsty for a cocktail. I ordered their passionfruit kombucha (looove) and vodka drink. That was very very tasty. Just what I needed after a long day plus a bike ride.   I wasn't too hungry, so I just ordered a bowl of soup and kale chips to munch with my friend. While the kale chips was bit under my expectation, the curry cauliflower soup was very comforting to my stomach. It's the kind of dish you want to make and savor at home.   My friend ordered the same soup (ugh copy cat), and the stuffed bell pepper dish. Unfortunately the stuffed red pepper did not delight us in any way. The spaghetti sauce like thing strangely looking too stiff and sitting top of the pepper  .... not really appetizing visually, and didn't taste good either.  So on my first try, some hits and misses. I'll gladly bike to here again and sip a cocktail. By the way, check out the interior - it's lovely.

When it comes to vegetarian eating, this restaurant is one of my favorites. Whenever I'm feeling "healthy" and visiting my brother in Madison, this is my restaurant of choice.  The food is surprisingly delicious and the options are all tempting and deliver on that promise. Seriously, the jambalaya is one of my favorites here.  Although today I had the most delicious sweet potato meal. It had this wonderful crunch comprised of chopped peanuts. OMG  The restaurant is clean and modern inside, but when the weather is reasonable we like to sit outside under the umbrellas.  Get the coffee.  Comes in individual French presses and will blow you away.

From the outside the Green Owl Cafe looks like a hole in the wall bar. A kitschy place. Once you get inside, the clean sherbet colors immediately elevate your mood. I especially appreciated the back wall of the place which was painted with orange and white birch trees.   Our server was a kind woman who knew the menu inside and out, but didn't take it for granted when we needed a little extra time to drool over the many vegan and vegetarian options.  I got the roasted veggie sandwich which featured beautiful crusty bread, roasted beets and sweet potatoes and other goodies. It was marvelous. I shared with my partner who got a TLT with avocado. Again, the bread was beautiful, the avocado was ripe, and the combination of tomato and seitan was very satisfying. The kale crips melt in your mouth.   I eavesdropped on our neighbors who had a bunch of questions for the server which she answered with ease. She was patient and didn't make anyone feel dumb for asking what anything was on the menu.   Overall, excellent lunch stop in Madison. Well worth it.

I'm not Vegan. I make this claim so I can convince you how awesome this place is. I've tried traditional Schnitzels of all kinds in the Midwest and Germany. I've made them myself at home. But the Vegan Schnitz at Green Owl bests them all. The Oven roasted potatoes were also superb. The Broccoli was meh, but frankly I was too busy enjoying the other stuff on my plate to fret about it.

This is our first trip to Madison's Green Owl Cafe, and I think it's a very okay vegetarian diner. I ordered the Cajun Blackened Tofu with a side cup of chili. The chili was awesome, just spicy enough and very flavorful. The tofu sandwich left me a tiny bit disappointed. It was surprisingly bland, and too "mooshy" to be held comfortably as a sandwich.  Lori ordered the Pesto Alfredo, which she said was very good. We ate outside on a sunny spring day, and that was very pleasant.  The wait staff was attentive, although a tad slower than I expected. Not bad, though.  I'll return for sure, I want to try something else!

Yesterday was my 4th time eating at The Green Owl since it opened.  As a vegetarian I really appreciate being able to go to a strictly veggie establishment.  Recently I purchased a Groupon for Green Owl and as a belated b-day gift, my friends took me there for brunch.    They had a good crowd that day when we went.  We were able to get a table right away.  The service was okay.  And I mean just okay.  I ordered the biscuits and gravy and a mimosa.  Thank goodness me and my friends had stuff to talk about because it seemed like a long time for us to get our food.  When the food arrived I was disappointed.  Why you ask?  As I looked at my plate, I observed one ordinary sized biscuit with some liquid-y brown 'gravy' over it.  And not much gravy.  Along with the biscuit there was literally a small handful of red potatoes.  The taste?  A bit of overkill on the seasonings in the biscuit and the gravy was okay; the potatoes were good.  My friends tempeh bacon was overcooked but he ate it anyway.  As mentioned above, I like the fact Madison has a veg only restaurant, but there are better places for veg food that offer larger portions for the price you pay.  I really, really, really want to like Green Owl but the prices for the amount of food on your plate has me frequenting other establishments.    If you are ever visiting Chicago, go to the Chicago Diner.  They excel at vegetarian/vegan food.

i hate to admit it. but i'm more impressed with the seasonal cocktails, the charming decor and the waitstaff than the actual food the restaurant provides.  still, i think this place offers an excellent and much-needed service to the vegetarian/vegan crowd.

So I brought my big meat-eating boyfriend here him unknowingly that it was vegetarian:) and we were delighted! We both got the BLT with tempeh on gluten free bread. The favors were definitely there, the tempeh was very good, nothing like bacon, but that's ok! Where Green Owl fell short was the gf bread fell completely apart. The sandwich was comparatively small and very crumbly, we both had to eat with a knife and fork. The kale chips (also a small portion for $3.50 when it's just kale) and quinoa salad, also very good! Overall great flavors, would have liked to eat my sandwich with two hands.

I'm happy to report that I've been back to The Green Owl a few times since my review, and it's gotten better and better each time. I would say that it is now a solid 4 stars. Their nightly specials have been more naturally vegetarian food rather than fake meat, and have been great! I had the "vegetable strudel (vegan) with roasted red pepper sauce--phyllo dough wrapped roasted vegetables topped with red pepper sauce, served with rice pilaf." It was beautifully presented and tasty. The vegan phyllo was impressively buttery tasting. We also got the fish fry, which seems to be on the menu each Friday night now. I don't really know my Wisconsin fish fries, with the last time I had fish being 17 years ago, but it was delicious!  The vegan cheese cake was surprisingly tangy (in a good, cheesecakey way) and all around awesome.  I'm still not thrilled about the soups, which is surprising since the owner is pretty much "the soup lady" for Mother Fool's and other spots around town - the lentils in the dal weren't fully cooked, and my chili had so much tomato that I couldn't taste much else. They aren't terrible . . . but I would recommend a salad over the soup as a starter.

Came here for lunch with a groupon yesterday, and overall I liked the food and the fact that Green Owl offers vegan/vegetarian food.  I was a bit surprised at the prices of the dishes, especially because the portion sizes were not particularly big. I was still a bit hungry after our late lunch here, and I don't think I eat all that much. With the groupon we got a good deal, but had we paid full price I think I would have been less happy with our experience here.  We split the Mediterranean Wrap and the Tempeh Jambalaya. The wrap was delicious, with a very fresh tabbouleh and lots of hummus. I felt it was a bit under-stuffed, as I was left with a ton of empty wrap at the ends. We got kale crisps with the wrap, which were delicious. The jambalaya was pretty good, though it was lacking some of the spicy cajun flavor I expect from jambalaya. The tempeh in it was really delicious though.   The main thing I disliked about Green Owl is the fact that most of the dishes they have on the menu are vegetarian versions of meat-centric dishes, and therefore they mainly use meat substitutes. I personally do not care for most meat substitutes, and I think vegan/vegetarian food should emphasize the large abundance of vegetables and lentils/grains with which you can make delicious dishes rather than trying to imitate meat. This is obviously a matter of personal preference, but I have to say I was disappointed to find that Green Owl focuses so much on meat substitutes.  Long story short, this place has some yummy vegan and vegetarian food. I wish it was a bit less expensive or they served a bit more, but this is a good lunch spot...especially if you go in the summer and snag an outdoor table!

I am not a vegetarian, but I requested to return to The Green Owl after a delicious meal 2 years ago (vegetarian is a hard sell with my friends).  The menu held several items I wanted to try, but I ordered the Cajun lemon tofu burger on the advice of the waitress.  My friend got the nightly taco special, and we started with the humus and baba ganoush appetizer.  The humus didn't have any flavor, but the baba ganoush made up for it.  My sandwich was delish and hardy, while my friend said her tacos were really good.  The disappointment came at the end of the meal, when I realized the desserts had not changed.  They offer fab desserts, but only 1 chocolate option.   I would go back in a heartbeat, because I feel good eating vegetarian, and the food is so darn good!

I have been a vegetarian my whole life, and sometimes going out for dinner is a little bit of a struggle choosing something. I'm so happy to have Green Owl Cafe in Madison for this reason! It's so nice to find a place I can order anything off the menu and not worry if there is bacon in the salad or if the soups are made out of chicken or meat broth.   My favorite foods I have tried at Green Owl so far are their Dare Devil wings, which are their version of spicy hot wings. It comes with vegan ranch which is a delicious combo with their wings. Also their peanut noodle bowl is delicious and amazing. I devoured it in minutes and left me quite satisfied. The Madison Philly is amazing and it has a great taste as well! The sand which also comes with a side!  There are only 2 things that are stopping me from giving Green Owl Cafe 5 stars. First, it is the lack of available parking which can be somewhat of an annoyance especially when you are starving. Also the service can be somewhat spotty and not consistent.
The Green Owl is great, because it has all the ingredients that Madison foodies want, but it isn't pretentious. I love the TLT!

Things that were really cool about this place: * It's all vegetarian/vegan. I'm a vegetarian. I rarely get this chance to have the WHOLE MENU!!! to look through (and vegans have it much worse). I was a little overwhelmed with the options, but don't worry, I pulled through. * It looks kinda dirty and dusty from the outside, but then it's beautiful, light, airy on the inside. * Alcohol! * You get a tiny French press for coffee  Not as impressive: * My food :( I ordered the nuevos rancheros, and it just tasted dry and bland. YOU CAN DO SO MUCH BETTER! The scrambled eggs were a little weird, and the kind I would usually make at home, because I fail. Derek's meal -- beer caramelized onions & cheese omelet -- was also pretty tasteless, which is hard to do with beer caramelized onions. Right? * We were seated three tables away from the front door/bar area. It wasn't a very busy Sunday brunch time, and there weren't customers around us (they were all in the back). So, no surprise that we could hear the "super cool" hipster kid and the other "super cool" hipster kid complaining about stupid customers in general. Things like how customers ask if they have dessert, which isn't listed on the menu but at the front of the restaurant. Oh I'm sorry, I didn't realize it was common practice for customers to get up and look around the restaurant for dessert listings.  I was pretty disappointed. We'll try again, possibly for lunch or dinner next time. Please impress us then!

SO .. I am not a vegan, but I have some family that is and when I am with them we usually go vegan and I don't mind.  I'll tell you what .... if this restaurant was in the western burbs ... I could easily go vegan and eat here daily.  I had the Vegan Schnitzel and the sauce on it was phenomenal for no cream or no dairy butter.  vegan protein is chewier, but when you get past that, and you have sauce on it, you can't really tell if you were eating a real piece of meat or not.  That is what makes this place awesome.  I would definitely come back and try other dishes!

Our dinner was amazing! We had the avocado salad, kale chips, a mushroom soup and tacos with rice and beans! It all tasted delicious! Dessert: Vegan-GF-SF-Coconut Pie and a Mojito cheesecake! Incredible!!!!!

I've come once before for brunch and did not leave satisfied. Wanted to give the green owl another chance because it's one of the few places in Madison dedicated to vegetarian/vegan food. My visit was average. Arrived at around 5 on a Tuesday and got seated immediately. They do have free wifi but I think they turn it off around dinner time--unsure about that.  I ordered the Buffalo wings and a side of the roasted potatoes. If you used to eat meat like me but no longer do, sometimes you may crave the taste of certain food you used to eat. For me, it's wings (more specially the Buffalo sauce). The wings are a decent fix for that craving, nothing out of this world but okay. It comes with 4 pieces, a side of ranch and some celery. The roasted potatoes were pretty disappointing. Just a bit chewy and not very flavorful. I ended up packing most of it to go.  The service was decent as well. It was nice to look at a menu and actually be able to eat everything on it, but I'm not too sure about how often I'll come back. I did want to try jackfruit in vegetarian food, so maybe I'll try that next time.

Ok, this place looks and feels exactly like you think it would. Weird lighting, weird colors and no meat to be found.  There is an eclectic collection of owl art and the back room sports some pretty yellowish orange hues. The cute little owls help the ambiance a lot.  The drinks are pretty rad and the specialty cocktail for Halloween was super tasty. Can't go wrong with booze I suppose. My GF had the Brekkie sandwich and it was pretty yummy. My biscuits and gravy on the other hand were a bit concerning. The gravy was like a spicy mortar made for securing your adobe home on the playa, now for eating. I've never had hot gravy that you shape into other food... The biscuit below seemed nice but the spice in the "gravy" overshadowed it. I will say the potatoes were super tasty and should have gotten a plate of those as a meal... Service was ok but she was a little frantic in trying to keep up so maybe they were a little understaffed?  I'd like to return for the non brunch menu and give it another go but first impressions are that this place is hit or miss. Hoot.

After trying a vegan chocolate cake from Whole Foods and thinking it was absolutely disgusting, I wasn't sure I'd buy into the vegan deal again.  Alas, my very good friend love love loves this place, so I thought I'd try it with her.    I had the special that day which was billed as vegan, but I added cheddar cheese - fried green tomato sandwich with spicy aioli, with potatoes.  Woah.  So very very good.  I didn't think that vegan bread could be that good, but it was crusty, a little flakey, but soft on the inside... perfect really.  And... I got potatoes to make sure I was full, and they were pretty good, but I'd recommend the kale chips.  You can get potatoes anywhere.  The wait staff was wonderful - we were there at 3, with zero other customers.  The ladies were chatting and hanging out near the bar, but they were very attentive to us - I thought our server read my mind when she appeared with water just as I was thinking that I'd like more.  She was also gracious with my skepticism... not much more I could ask for.   Give it a try!

My boyfriend is vegan (although he eats fish now, so what's that? pescan?) and so we went to check this place out shortly after the grand opening with some of our friends.  Tucked away in a cozy corner of Atwood St, the Green Owl definitely exceeded expectations. Specializing in homey comfort vegan/vegetarian cuisine, the meals there are simple but tasty.   My favorites:  The crabby cakes- rich, melt in your mouth flavor. It's hard to imagine that this actually doesn't have an ounce of crab in it. I'd say this is probably one of the best dishes on the menu.   BBQ Jackfruit sandwich- a refreshing take on the pulled pork sandwich. The combination of fresh vinegary coleslaw and the jackfruit was suprising but worked well.   The bread and spread- Green Owl features an appetizer special that features a daily homemade spread. The one we had was a beet and horseradish creation. The odd combination was delightfully tangy and spicy. I could eat tubs of that stuff.   I'm looking forward to visiting again.

We dined at The Green Owl for dinner on Valentine's Day (a Friday night) and for Sunday brunch.  On Valentine's Day, they had some fancier specials like stuffed shells with garlic bread (all vegan!).  Great spot for regular dining and for special occasions.
ALL VEGETARIAN AND MOSTLY VEGAN  Amazing!!!  Got the crabby cakes, fish sandwich special, and Schnitzel.   Also loads of free deserts. All amazing and great food and i can not wait to go back.

We stopped here for "brunch" in early May 2013 on a drive from Providence, RI, to Billings, MT after seeing yelp reviews for vegan/vegetarian places in Madison. The vegan sausage was delicious and the breakfast food in general was very good (I had vegetarian Nuevos Rancheros with vegan chorizo). The coffee was great after driving about 20 hours.
